appendix.title: Brief history of the NeXus format

listitem.para: Mark Koennecke (then ISIS, now PSI) made a proposal using netCDF for the European neutron scattering community while working at ISIS
Jonathan Tischler and Mitch Nelson (ORNL) proposed an HDF-based format as a standard for data storage at APS

At SoftNeSS 1995 (at NIST) The then existing three individual data format proposals by Przemek Klososki (NIST), Jonathan Tischler (APS) and Mark Koennnecke (then ISIS) were joined to form the basis of the current NeXus format. After reviewing the different scientific data formats available in 1996, it was decided to use HDF-4 as it provided the best grouping support. The basic structure of a NeXus file was agreed upon. At SoftNeSS 1996 (at ANL) the NeXus proposal was refined some more.
The HDF-4 API is quite complex. Thus a NeXus Abstract Programmer Interface (NAPI) was released which simplified reading and writing NeXus files
SINQ at PSI started writing NeXus files to store raw data.
MLNSC at LANL started writing NeXus files to store raw data

NeXus API version 2.0.0 is released. This version brought support for the new version of HDF, HDF-5, released by the HDF group. HDF-4 imposed limits on file sizes and the number of objects in a file. These issues were resolved with HDF-5. The NeXus API abstracted the difference between the tow physical file formats away form the user.

In 2003, NeXus had arrived at a stage where informal gatherings of a group of people were no longer good enough to oversee the development of NeXus. This lead to the formation of the NeXus International Advisory Committee (NIAC) which strives to include representatives of all major stake holders in NeXus. A first meeting was held at CalTech. Since 2003, the NIAC meets very year to discuss all matters NeXus.

The community asked the NeXus team to provide an ASCII based physical file format which allows them to edit their scientific results in emacs. This lead to the development of a XML NeXus physical format. This was released with NeXus API version 3.0.0.
NeXus API version 4.0.0 is released with broader support for scripting languages and the feauture to link with external files.

The NeXus Definition Language (NXDL) is defined. Before NXDL NeXus used another XML format, meta-DTD, for defining base classes and application definitions. There were several problems with meta-DTD, the biggest one being that it was not easy to validate against it. NXDL was designed to circumvent these problems and all current nase classes and application definitions were ported into the NXDL.
NXDL and draft NXsas presented to canSAS at SAS2009 conference
NXDL presented to ESRF HDF5 workshop on hyperspectral data
